nodes.text: Lexicon-based Hedonometer sentiment scores differ from machine-learning based Azure scores and these differences may be driven by particular Hedonometer lexical entries and vary by domain
Method: Compute sentiment scores for 150,000+ English texts from four domains (Finance, News, Social Media, IMDB) using Hedonometer and Microsoft Azure Text Analytics

Method: Model differences between Hedonometer and Azure sentiment scores per domain using linear regression with Hedonometer lexical entries as independent variables and examine variable significance (p-values)
Context: Hedonometer is a lexicon of 10,222 English words with context-free happiness scores from crowdsourced ratings; Azure returns sentiment in [0,1]
Assumption: Azure is used as a reference standard to which Hedonometer outputs are mapped and differences are interpreted relative to Azure
Result: The number of Hedonometer words present differs by domain: Finance 966, News 274, Social media 1,886, IMDB 2,673 (3,810 unique words across domains)

Result: Visual comparison shows approximate agreement between Hedonometer and Azure in Finance and News, greater differences in Social Media, and extreme differences for IMDB reviews due to narrower Hedonometer score range

Result: Regression p-values identify words with smallest p-values (words whose Hedonometer weights would need change to match Azure) and words with largest p-values (words interpreted similarly by both methods)
Method: Restrict analysis to words that appear in Hedonometer lexicon and in at least three of the four domains to find consistent outlier words across domains
Claim: Word importance for explaining Hedonometer-Azure differences depends on domain because different Hedonometer subsets appear in each domain
Result: There are no major outlier Hedonometer words that consistently cause differences across domains; only the word "mom" appears as extreme in more than one domain

Result: Spearman correlations between Hedonometer happiness rank and regression p-value rank are weak: Finance -0.1126, News -0.1206, Social media 0.2949, IMDB 0.3300, indicating only small association between Hedonometer score and contribution to differences
Limitation: Analysis covers only 3,810 of 10,222 Hedonometer words because many lexicon entries do not appear in the four domain datasets, limiting generalisability

Limitation and Claim: Use of linear regression with many lexical independent variables raises multiple hypothesis testing concerns and may affect p-values; non-parametric ML feature-importance could be an alternative

Conclusion: Domain matters for which Hedonometer words influence differences, but there are no systematic single-word causes of large differences; adjusting Hedonometer weights is unlikely to substantially change overall sentiment outputs and consistent use across comparisons is more important
